Fee-based

The overall objective of this TA operation is “to foster employment generating activities and promoting access to finance to MSEs and low income persons of the Southern Neighbourhood of the EU, with the ultimate goal of sustaining job creation, socio-economic growth and to contribute to poverty alleviation, therefore directly addressing the causes of migration.”
The specific objectives of this TA operation are:
i) To facilitate the deployment of EIB medium to long term resources granted to selected Financial Institutions for the benefit of local beneficiaries;

ii) To strengthen the financial and managerial capacity of the selected Financial Institutions so as to ensure that the Final Beneficiaries are served by sustainable, responsible and well managed Financial Institutions;

iii) To contribute towards unemployment reduction by offering populations in the Southern Neighbourhood improved access to a diverse and responsible range of financial and nonfinancial products aimed at encouraging income generation;
iv) To safeguard the EIB’s reputation and investments by ensuring that Financial Institutions have sound credit risk management procedures in place and serve a growing number of creditworthy clients;
v) To improve loan processing and deployment efficiency and facilitate the contractual relationship between the Financial institutions and the EIB;
In order to achieve these objectives, the TA programme comprises three components which are as follows:
a) Component 1. Training programmes for Financial Intermediaries.

Under Component 1 the Consultant is expected to design and provide Financial Intermediaries with training and mentoring, to support the sourcing, processing and management of microfinance operations under the Facility. The overall aim of component 1 is to ensure the management of creditworthy and sound loan applications protecting the Facility and the Financial Intermediaries from credit and reputational risks. Additionally, the aim is to ensure compliance of EIB Financial Intermediaries with standard EIB conditions attached to credit lines.
b) Component 2. Capacity building via consulting interventions for Financial Intermediaries.

Component 2 is aimed at providing customised technical assistance support to Financial Intermediaries by addressing specific weaknesses in a variety of areas and helping them to strengthen their financial management and governance according to internationally accepted sector and banking professional and regulatory standards.

Activities under component 2 should contribute to ensuring the long term viability / sustainability of the Financial Intermediaries’ operations according to specific need. They are expected to be performed in but not limited to areas such as product offer diversification and market assessment, transformation, risk management and monitoring, information technology (data processing, innovation, process efficiency), governance, social performance management and transparency.

c) Component 3. Support actions and training aimed at improving the level of financial literacy, improving managerial capacity and building entrepreneurship skills of current and potential Final Beneficiaries.

The aim of component 3 is to organise trainings and coaching for current and potential Final Beneficiaries to improve their level of financial literacy and improve their managerial capacity and entrepreneurial skills.

The following selection criteria will be applied to candidates. In the case of applications submitted by a consortium, these selection criteria will be applied to the consortium as a whole:
1) Economic and financial capacity of candidate (based on item 3 of the application form). In case of applicant being a public body, equivalent information should be provided.

(a) The annual turnover (if the candidate is an individual company) or the combined annual turnover (if the candidate is a consortium) of the candidate must be at least 1 500 000 EUR for each of the last 3 years (2017, 2016 and 2015) for which accounts have been closed.
(b) The average of cash and cash equivalents at the end and beginning of each year for the years 2017, 2016 and 2015 are positive.
2) Professional capacity of candidate (based on items 4 and 5 of the application form)

(a) The number of the permanent staff of the candidate (individual company or consortium overall) currently working in fields related to this contract (as they are described in item 7 – “Contract Description” above), must be at least 10 for each of the last three years (2017, 2016 and 2015).
Note to candidates: In the application form, please make sure to include the actual year for which the data is provided.
3) Technical capacity of candidate (based on items 5 and 6 of the application form)

(a) The candidate (individual company or consortium altogether) has successfully implemented, during the last 5 years (up to the deadline for the receipt of applications indicated under item 23 below), technical assistance operations in the (inclusive) financial sector as follows:

i. At least 4 technical assistance operations in the inclusive financial sector with an equivalent minimum value of 250 000 EUR each. The referenced projects should demonstrate the candidate’s track record in providing training programmes and capacity building measures to commercial banks and/or microfinance institutions in areas such as, but not limited to, governance, transformation, information technology (data processing, innovation, process efficiency), financial and social performance, risk management, the EIB’s social and environmental standards, and/or Micro and SME (M/SME) lending and product diversification.

ii. At least 4 technical assistance operations focused on improving the financial literacy and managerial skills of final beneficiaries with an equivalent minimum value of 100 000 EUR each. Referenced projects should include activities related to providing direct support (including developing and/or rolling out vocational training/coaching courses) to micro, small and medium sized enterprises in areas such as business plan preparation, entrepreneurship skills, financial literacy and education, and improvement of managerial capacity.
iii. The candidate should demonstrate that it had a minimum participation rate in all referenced projects of at least 50 %.
iv. At least one reference regarding for each criterion (3a.i and 3a.ii) must be provided by the lead company in the case of a consortium.
Note to candidates:

A maximum number of 15 projects may be referenced all of which must have been completed within the last 5 years up to the submission deadline as specified in point 23. – I.e. they must have been completed between May 2013 and May 2018. Where the projects referenced have been implemented by consortia comprising two or more of the members now associated as a consortium for this tender procedure, their respective percentages shall be added together, in order for the application to be assessed on the basis of the consortium as a whole.
Please do not submit referenced projects that are not strictly compliant with the above criteria.

Such entities, for instance the parent company of the economic operator, must respect the same rules of eligibility and notably that of nationality, as the economic operator.

If more than 8 eligible candidates meet the above selection criteria, the relative strengths and weaknesses of the applications of these candidates must be re-examined to identify the eight best applications for the tender procedure. The only factors which will be taken into consideration during this re-examination are, in order of precedence:

1) The number of projects which comply with the requirements of criteria 3(a.i) and 3(a.ii) implemented in one of the following countries: Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, Egypt, Lebanon, Jordan, Palestine and Syria.
2) The number of projects brought as references which comply with the requirements of criterion 3(a.i);
3) The number of projects brought as references which comply with the requirements of criteria 3(a.i) and 3(a.ii);
4) The value of projects brought as references which comply with the requirements of criterion 3(a.i).
Best value for money.

i) To facilitate the deployment of EIB medium to long term resources granted to selected Financial Institutions for the benefit of local beneficiaries;

ii) To strengthen the financial and managerial capacity of the selected Financial Institutions so as to ensure that the Final Beneficiaries are served by sustainable, responsible and well managed Financial Institutions;

iii) To contribute towards unemployment reduction by offering populations in the Southern Neighbourhood improved access to a diverse and responsible range of financial and nonfinancial products aimed at encouraging income generation;
iv) To safeguard the EIB’s reputation and investments by ensuring that Financial Institutions have sound credit risk management procedures in place and serve a growing number of creditworthy clients;
v) To improve loan processing and deployment efficiency and facilitate the contractual relationship between the Financial institutions and the EIB;
In order to achieve these objectives, the TA programme comprises three components which are as follows:
a) Component 1. Training programmes for Financial Intermediaries.

Under Component 1 the Consultant is expected to design and provide Financial Intermediaries with training and mentoring, to support the sourcing, processing and management of microfinance operations under the Facility. The overall aim of component 1 is to ensure the management of creditworthy and sound loan applications protecting the Facility and the Financial Intermediaries from credit and reputational risks. Additionally, the aim is to ensure compliance of EIB Financial Intermediaries with standard EIB conditions attached to credit lines.
b) Component 2. Capacity building via consulting interventions for Financial Intermediaries.

Component 2 is aimed at providing customised technical assistance support to Financial Intermediaries by addressing specific weaknesses in a variety of areas and helping them to strengthen their financial management and governance according to internationally accepted sector and banking professional and regulatory standards.

Activities under component 2 should contribute to ensuring the long term viability / sustainability of the Financial Intermediaries’ operations according to specific need. They are expected to be performed in but not limited to areas such as product offer diversification and market assessment, transformation, risk management and monitoring, information technology (data processing, innovation, process efficiency), governance, social performance management and transparency.

c) Component 3. Support actions and training aimed at improving the level of financial literacy, improving managerial capacity and building entrepreneurship skills of current and potential Final Beneficiaries.

The aim of component 3 is to organise trainings and coaching for current and potential Final Beneficiaries to improve their level of financial literacy and improve their managerial capacity and entrepreneurial skills.

The overall objective of this TA operation is “to foster employment generating activities and promoting access to finance to MSEs and low income persons of the Southern Neighbourhood of the EU, with the ultimate goal of sustaining job creation, socio-economic growth and to contribute to poverty alleviation, therefore directly addressing the causes of migration.”
The specific objectives of this TA operation are:
i) To facilitate the deployment of EIB medium to long term resources granted to selected Financial Institutions for the benefit of local beneficiaries;

ii) To strengthen the financial and managerial capacity of the selected Financial Institutions so as to ensure that the Final Beneficiaries are served by sustainable, responsible and well managed Financial Institutions;

iii) To contribute towards unemployment reduction by offering populations in the Southern Neighbourhood improved access to a diverse and responsible range of financial and nonfinancial products aimed at encouraging income generation;
iv) To safeguard the EIB’s reputation and investments by ensuring that Financial Institutions have sound credit risk management procedures in place and serve a growing number of creditworthy clients;
v) To improve loan processing and deployment efficiency and facilitate the contractual relationship between the Financial institutions and the EIB;
In order to achieve these objectives, the TA programme comprises three components which are as follows:
a) Component 1. Training programmes for Financial Intermediaries.

Under Component 1 the Consultant is expected to design and provide Financial Intermediaries with training and mentoring, to support the sourcing, processing and management of microfinance operations under the Facility. The overall aim of component 1 is to ensure the management of creditworthy and sound loan applications protecting the Facility and the Financial Intermediaries from credit and reputational risks. Additionally, the aim is to ensure compliance of EIB Financial Intermediaries with standard EIB conditions attached to credit lines.
b) Component 2. Capacity building via consulting interventions for Financial Intermediaries.

Component 2 is aimed at providing customised technical assistance support to Financial Intermediaries by addressing specific weaknesses in a variety of areas and helping them to strengthen their financial management and governance according to internationally accepted sector and banking professional and regulatory standards.

Activities under component 2 should contribute to ensuring the long term viability / sustainability of the Financial Intermediaries’ operations according to specific need. They are expected to be performed in but not limited to areas such as product offer diversification and market assessment, transformation, risk management and monitoring, information technology (data processing, innovation, process efficiency), governance, social performance management and transparency.

c) Component 3. Support actions and training aimed at improving the level of financial literacy, improving managerial capacity and building entrepreneurship skills of current and potential Final Beneficiaries.

The aim of component 3 is to organise trainings and coaching for current and potential Final Beneficiaries to improve their level of financial literacy and improve their managerial capacity and entrepreneurial skills.

i) To facilitate the deployment of EIB medium to long term resources granted to selected Financial Institutions for the benefit of local beneficiaries;

ii) To strengthen the financial and managerial capacity of the selected Financial Institutions so as to ensure that the Final Beneficiaries are served by sustainable, responsible and well managed Financial Institutions;

iii) To contribute towards unemployment reduction by offering populations in the Southern Neighbourhood improved access to a diverse and responsible range of financial and nonfinancial products aimed at encouraging income generation;
iv) To safeguard the EIB’s reputation and investments by ensuring that Financial Institutions have sound credit risk management procedures in place and serve a growing number of creditworthy clients;
v) To improve loan processing and deployment efficiency and facilitate the contractual relationship between the Financial institutions and the EIB;
In order to achieve these objectives, the TA programme comprises three components which are as follows:
a) Component 1. Training programmes for Financial Intermediaries.

Under Component 1 the Consultant is expected to design and provide Financial Intermediaries with training and mentoring, to support the sourcing, processing and management of microfinance operations under the Facility. The overall aim of component 1 is to ensure the management of creditworthy and sound loan applications protecting the Facility and the Financial Intermediaries from credit and reputational risks. Additionally, the aim is to ensure compliance of EIB Financial Intermediaries with standard EIB conditions attached to credit lines.
b) Component 2. Capacity building via consulting interventions for Financial Intermediaries.

Component 2 is aimed at providing customised technical assistance support to Financial Intermediaries by addressing specific weaknesses in a variety of areas and helping them to strengthen their financial management and governance according to internationally accepted sector and banking professional and regulatory standards.

Activities under component 2 should contribute to ensuring the long term viability / sustainability of the Financial Intermediaries’ operations according to specific need. They are expected to be performed in but not limited to areas such as product offer diversification and market assessment, transformation, risk management and monitoring, information technology (data processing, innovation, process efficiency), governance, social performance management and transparency.

c) Component 3. Support actions and training aimed at improving the level of financial literacy, improving managerial capacity and building entrepreneurship skills of current and potential Final Beneficiaries.

The aim of component 3 is to organise trainings and coaching for current and potential Final Beneficiaries to improve their level of financial literacy and improve their managerial capacity and entrepreneurial skills.

The overall objective of this TA operation is “to foster employment generating activities and promoting access to finance to MSEs and low income persons of the Southern Neighbourhood of the EU, with the ultimate goal of sustaining job creation, socio-economic growth and to contribute to poverty alleviation, therefore directly addressing the causes of migration.”
The specific objectives of this TA operation are:
i) To facilitate the deployment of EIB medium to long term resources granted to selected Financial Institutions for the benefit of local beneficiaries;

ii) To strengthen the financial and managerial capacity of the selected Financial Institutions so as to ensure that the Final Beneficiaries are served by sustainable, responsible and well managed Financial Institutions;

iii) To contribute towards unemployment reduction by offering populations in the Southern Neighbourhood improved access to a diverse and responsible range of financial and nonfinancial products aimed at encouraging income generation;
iv) To safeguard the EIB’s reputation and investments by ensuring that Financial Institutions have sound credit risk management procedures in place and serve a growing number of creditworthy clients;
v) To improve loan processing and deployment efficiency and facilitate the contractual relationship between the Financial institutions and the EIB;
In order to achieve these objectives, the TA programme comprises three components which are as follows:
a) Component 1. Training programmes for Financial Intermediaries.

Under Component 1 the Consultant is expected to design and provide Financial Intermediaries with training and mentoring, to support the sourcing, processing and management of microfinance operations under the Facility. The overall aim of component 1 is to ensure the management of creditworthy and sound loan applications protecting the Facility and the Financial Intermediaries from credit and reputational risks. Additionally, the aim is to ensure compliance of EIB Financial Intermediaries with standard EIB conditions attached to credit lines.
b) Component 2. Capacity building via consulting interventions for Financial Intermediaries.

Component 2 is aimed at providing customised technical assistance support to Financial Intermediaries by addressing specific weaknesses in a variety of areas and helping them to strengthen their financial management and governance according to internationally accepted sector and banking professional and regulatory standards.

Activities under component 2 should contribute to ensuring the long term viability / sustainability of the Financial Intermediaries’ operations according to specific need. They are expected to be performed in but not limited to areas such as product offer diversification and market assessment, transformation, risk management and monitoring, information technology (data processing, innovation, process efficiency), governance, social performance management and transparency.

c) Component 3. Support actions and training aimed at improving the level of financial literacy, improving managerial capacity and building entrepreneurship skills of current and potential Final Beneficiaries.

The aim of component 3 is to organise trainings and coaching for current and potential Final Beneficiaries to improve their level of financial literacy and improve their managerial capacity and entrepreneurial skills.

i) To facilitate the deployment of EIB medium to long term resources granted to selected Financial Institutions for the benefit of local beneficiaries;

ii) To strengthen the financial and managerial capacity of the selected Financial Institutions so as to ensure that the Final Beneficiaries are served by sustainable, responsible and well managed Financial Institutions;

iii) To contribute towards unemployment reduction by offering populations in the Southern Neighbourhood improved access to a diverse and responsible range of financial and nonfinancial products aimed at encouraging income generation;
iv) To safeguard the EIB’s reputation and investments by ensuring that Financial Institutions have sound credit risk management procedures in place and serve a growing number of creditworthy clients;
v) To improve loan processing and deployment efficiency and facilitate the contractual relationship between the Financial institutions and the EIB;
In order to achieve these objectives, the TA programme comprises three components which are as follows:
a) Component 1. Training programmes for Financial Intermediaries.

Under Component 1 the Consultant is expected to design and provide Financial Intermediaries with training and mentoring, to support the sourcing, processing and management of microfinance operations under the Facility. The overall aim of component 1 is to ensure the management of creditworthy and sound loan applications protecting the Facility and the Financial Intermediaries from credit and reputational risks. Additionally, the aim is to ensure compliance of EIB Financial Intermediaries with standard EIB conditions attached to credit lines.
b) Component 2. Capacity building via consulting interventions for Financial Intermediaries.

Component 2 is aimed at providing customised technical assistance support to Financial Intermediaries by addressing specific weaknesses in a variety of areas and helping them to strengthen their financial management and governance according to internationally accepted sector and banking professional and regulatory standards.

Activities under component 2 should contribute to ensuring the long term viability / sustainability of the Financial Intermediaries’ operations according to specific need. They are expected to be performed in but not limited to areas such as product offer diversification and market assessment, transformation, risk management and monitoring, information technology (data processing, innovation, process efficiency), governance, social performance management and transparency.

c) Component 3. Support actions and training aimed at improving the level of financial literacy, improving managerial capacity and building entrepreneurship skills of current and potential Final Beneficiaries.

The aim of component 3 is to organise trainings and coaching for current and potential Final Beneficiaries to improve their level of financial literacy and improve their managerial capacity and entrepreneurial skills.

The overall objective of this TA operation is “to foster employment generating activities and promoting access to finance to MSEs and low income persons of the Southern Neighbourhood of the EU, with the ultimate goal of sustaining job creation, socio-economic growth and to contribute to poverty alleviation, therefore directly addressing the causes of migration.”
The specific objectives of this TA operation are:
i) To facilitate the deployment of EIB medium to long term resources granted to selected Financial Institutions for the benefit of local beneficiaries;

ii) To strengthen the financial and managerial capacity of the selected Financial Institutions so as to ensure that the Final Beneficiaries are served by sustainable, responsible and well managed Financial Institutions;

iii) To contribute towards unemployment reduction by offering populations in the Southern Neighbourhood improved access to a diverse and responsible range of financial and nonfinancial products aimed at encouraging income generation;
iv) To safeguard the EIB’s reputation and investments by ensuring that Financial Institutions have sound credit risk management procedures in place and serve a growing number of creditworthy clients;
v) To improve loan processing and deployment efficiency and facilitate the contractual relationship between the Financial institutions and the EIB;
In order to achieve these objectives, the TA programme comprises three components which are as follows:
a) Component 1. Training programmes for Financial Intermediaries.

Under Component 1 the Consultant is expected to design and provide Financial Intermediaries with training and mentoring, to support the sourcing, processing and management of microfinance operations under the Facility. The overall aim of component 1 is to ensure the management of creditworthy and sound loan applications protecting the Facility and the Financial Intermediaries from credit and reputational risks. Additionally, the aim is to ensure compliance of EIB Financial Intermediaries with standard EIB conditions attached to credit lines.
b) Component 2. Capacity building via consulting interventions for Financial Intermediaries.

Component 2 is aimed at providing customised technical assistance support to Financial Intermediaries by addressing specific weaknesses in a variety of areas and helping them to strengthen their financial management and governance according to internationally accepted sector and banking professional and regulatory standards.

Activities under component 2 should contribute to ensuring the long term viability / sustainability of the Financial Intermediaries’ operations according to specific need. They are expected to be performed in but not limited to areas such as product offer diversification and market assessment, transformation, risk management and monitoring, information technology (data processing, innovation, process efficiency), governance, social performance management and transparency.

c) Component 3. Support actions and training aimed at improving the level of financial literacy, improving managerial capacity and building entrepreneurship skills of current and potential Final Beneficiaries.

The aim of component 3 is to organise trainings and coaching for current and potential Final Beneficiaries to improve their level of financial literacy and improve their managerial capacity and entrepreneurial skills.

i) To facilitate the deployment of EIB medium to long term resources granted to selected Financial Institutions for the benefit of local beneficiaries;

ii) To strengthen the financial and managerial capacity of the selected Financial Institutions so as to ensure that the Final Beneficiaries are served by sustainable, responsible and well managed Financial Institutions;

iii) To contribute towards unemployment reduction by offering populations in the Southern Neighbourhood improved access to a diverse and responsible range of financial and nonfinancial products aimed at encouraging income generation;
iv) To safeguard the EIB’s reputation and investments by ensuring that Financial Institutions have sound credit risk management procedures in place and serve a growing number of creditworthy clients;
v) To improve loan processing and deployment efficiency and facilitate the contractual relationship between the Financial institutions and the EIB;
In order to achieve these objectives, the TA programme comprises three components which are as follows:
a) Component 1. Training programmes for Financial Intermediaries.

Under Component 1 the Consultant is expected to design and provide Financial Intermediaries with training and mentoring, to support the sourcing, processing and management of microfinance operations under the Facility. The overall aim of component 1 is to ensure the management of creditworthy and sound loan applications protecting the Facility and the Financial Intermediaries from credit and reputational risks. Additionally, the aim is to ensure compliance of EIB Financial Intermediaries with standard EIB conditions attached to credit lines.
b) Component 2. Capacity building via consulting interventions for Financial Intermediaries.

Component 2 is aimed at providing customised technical assistance support to Financial Intermediaries by addressing specific weaknesses in a variety of areas and helping them to strengthen their financial management and governance according to internationally accepted sector and banking professional and regulatory standards.

Activities under component 2 should contribute to ensuring the long term viability / sustainability of the Financial Intermediaries’ operations according to specific need. They are expected to be performed in but not limited to areas such as product offer diversification and market assessment, transformation, risk management and monitoring, information technology (data processing, innovation, process efficiency), governance, social performance management and transparency.

c) Component 3. Support actions and training aimed at improving the level of financial literacy, improving managerial capacity and building entrepreneurship skills of current and potential Final Beneficiaries.

The aim of component 3 is to organise trainings and coaching for current and potential Final Beneficiaries to improve their level of financial literacy and improve their managerial capacity and entrepreneurial skills.

The overall objective of this TA operation is “to foster employment generating activities and promoting access to finance to MSEs and low income persons of the Southern Neighbourhood of the EU, with the ultimate goal of sustaining job creation, socio-economic growth and to contribute to poverty alleviation, therefore directly addressing the causes of migration.”
The specific objectives of this TA operation are:
i) To facilitate the deployment of EIB medium to long term resources granted to selected Financial Institutions for the benefit of local beneficiaries;

ii) To strengthen the financial and managerial capacity of the selected Financial Institutions so as to ensure that the Final Beneficiaries are served by sustainable, responsible and well managed Financial Institutions;

iii) To contribute towards unemployment reduction by offering populations in the Southern Neighbourhood improved access to a diverse and responsible range of financial and nonfinancial products aimed at encouraging income generation;
iv) To safeguard the EIB’s reputation and investments by ensuring that Financial Institutions have sound credit risk management procedures in place and serve a growing number of creditworthy clients;
v) To improve loan processing and deployment efficiency and facilitate the contractual relationship between the Financial institutions and the EIB;
In order to achieve these objectives, the TA programme comprises three components which are as follows:
a) Component 1. Training programmes for Financial Intermediaries.

Under Component 1 the Consultant is expected to design and provide Financial Intermediaries with training and mentoring, to support the sourcing, processing and management of microfinance operations under the Facility. The overall aim of component 1 is to ensure the management of creditworthy and sound loan applications protecting the Facility and the Financial Intermediaries from credit and reputational risks. Additionally, the aim is to ensure compliance of EIB Financial Intermediaries with standard EIB conditions attached to credit lines.
b) Component 2. Capacity building via consulting interventions for Financial Intermediaries.

Component 2 is aimed at providing customised technical assistance support to Financial Intermediaries by addressing specific weaknesses in a variety of areas and helping them to strengthen their financial management and governance according to internationally accepted sector and banking professional and regulatory standards.

Activities under component 2 should contribute to ensuring the long term viability / sustainability of the Financial Intermediaries’ operations according to specific need. They are expected to be performed in but not limited to areas such as product offer diversification and market assessment, transformation, risk management and monitoring, information technology (data processing, innovation, process efficiency), governance, social performance management and transparency.

c) Component 3. Support actions and training aimed at improving the level of financial literacy, improving managerial capacity and building entrepreneurship skills of current and potential Final Beneficiaries.

The aim of component 3 is to organise trainings and coaching for current and potential Final Beneficiaries to improve their level of financial literacy and improve their managerial capacity and entrepreneurial skills.

The overall objective of this TA operation is “to foster employment generating activities and promoting access to finance to MSEs and low income persons of the Southern Neighbourhood of the EU, with the ultimate goal of sustaining job creation, socio-economic growth and to contribute to poverty alleviation, therefore directly addressing the causes of migration.”
The specific objectives of this TA operation are:
i) To facilitate the deployment of EIB medium to long term resources granted to selected Financial Institutions for the benefit of local beneficiaries;

ii) To strengthen the financial and managerial capacity of the selected Financial Institutions so as to ensure that the Final Beneficiaries are served by sustainable, responsible and well managed Financial Institutions;

iii) To contribute towards unemployment reduction by offering populations in the Southern Neighbourhood improved access to a diverse and responsible range of financial and nonfinancial products aimed at encouraging income generation;
iv) To safeguard the EIB’s reputation and investments by ensuring that Financial Institutions have sound credit risk management procedures in place and serve a growing number of creditworthy clients;
v) To improve loan processing and deployment efficiency and facilitate the contractual relationship between the Financial institutions and the EIB;
In order to achieve these objectives, the TA programme comprises three components which are as follows:
a) Component 1. Training programmes for Financial Intermediaries.

Under Component 1 the Consultant is expected to design and provide Financial Intermediaries with training and mentoring, to support the sourcing, processing and management of microfinance operations under the Facility. The overall aim of component 1 is to ensure the management of creditworthy and sound loan applications protecting the Facility and the Financial Intermediaries from credit and reputational risks. Additionally, the aim is to ensure compliance of EIB Financial Intermediaries with standard EIB conditions attached to credit lines.
b) Component 2. Capacity building via consulting interventions for Financial Intermediaries.

Component 2 is aimed at providing customised technical assistance support to Financial Intermediaries by addressing specific weaknesses in a variety of areas and helping them to strengthen their financial management and governance according to internationally accepted sector and banking professional and regulatory standards.

Activities under component 2 should contribute to ensuring the long term viability / sustainability of the Financial Intermediaries’ operations according to specific need. They are expected to be performed in but not limited to areas such as product offer diversification and market assessment, transformation, risk management and monitoring, information technology (data processing, innovation, process efficiency), governance, social performance management and transparency.

c) Component 3. Support actions and training aimed at improving the level of financial literacy, improving managerial capacity and building entrepreneurship skills of current and potential Final Beneficiaries.

The aim of component 3 is to organise trainings and coaching for current and potential Final Beneficiaries to improve their level of financial literacy and improve their managerial capacity and entrepreneurial skills.
